p.s: Description of Pasteurella lymphangitidis sp. nov.
Pasteurella lymphangitidis (lymph.ang.it'id.is. M.L. gen. n. lymphangitidis, pertaining to lymphangitis, inflammation of the lymph nodes)
The BL (bovine lymphangitis) bacterium of Jayaraman and Sethumadavan (18); phenon 4 of Sneath and Stevens (46).
Cells are nonmotile bacilli, with some coccobacilli.
Growth is aerobic and facultatively anaerobic, mesophilic.

Surface colonies grown aerobically on sheep blood agar are round, greyish, semitransparent, about 2.5 mm in diameter after 48 h at 37Â°C, and nonhemolytic but sometimes showing greening of the erythrocytes.
Notable for not reducing nitrate, in being sensitive to azide, for acidifying arbutin, and for giving a negative oxidase reaction (46).
In our hands galactose and mannose were acidified, although both of these reactions were recorded as negative by Jayaraman and Sethumadavan (18).
Other properties are shown in Table 2.
Isolated from lymphangitis in Bos indicus in Southern India (18).
Weak serological cross-reactions have been reported with A. lignieresii and Yersinia pseudotuberculosis (18).
Phenotypically, this organism has some weak affinities with members of the genus Yersinia (46), but is evidently allied to the Actinobacillus-Pasteurella complex (46).
DNA-DNA pairing tests show low values (less than 30%) to P. multocida, P. pneumotropica, P. ureae, A. lignieresii, A. equuli, and A. suis (13, 28).
In our hands this organism was variable for the tests marked d in Table 2.
The G+C content of the DNA of the type strain is 49.7 mol% (Tm method) (28).
The type strain is strain NCTC 10547 (= Jayaraman strain I = A82 = 71) (28, 46).
In our hands this strain was negative for the tests marked d in Table 2, except for late reactions in the tests for acid production from maltose and salicin.
